titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Collège de la Sainte Famille Collection AD.MC.028
titlestmt.author: Jasmine Soliman and Jonathan Burr for Akkasah: Center for Photography NYUAD

publicationstmt.publisher: Akkasah: Center for Photography (NYU Abu Dhabi)

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2021-05-21 18:32:44 +0400.

repository.corpname: Akkasah: Center for Photography (NYU Abu Dhabi)

did.unittitle: College de la Sainte Famille Collection

physdesc.extent: - 1,402 photographs, digital surrogates only retained by Akkasah: Center for Photography.

did.abstract: The images in this collection document the history of the The Collège Sainte Famille in Cairo, Egypt. The Collège Sainte Famille (CSF) was founded in 1887 by Casimiro Giacomelli, a priest of the Comboni Missionaries who had previously been posted in Sudan. CSF was a private initiative to serve the local population of Helwan (some 25km south of central Cairo) – Egyptian and foreign, Christian and Muslim. At the time of its founding, Egypt had a fledgling public education system and several churches established schools with official endorsement. Known today as the Holy Family School, it remains Helwan's oldest and most distinguished school. It has evolved from being an entirely European initiative to being an Egyptian school in all respects. Its administrators, teachers, and pupils hail largely from the local neighborhood, although a few dozen students travel from across the Nile or adjacent neighborhoods to the north. CSF-Helwan carries on as a private institution administered by the Comboni Missionaries.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The images in this collection document the history of the The Collège de la Sainte Famille in Cairo, Egypt. The Collège Sainte Famille (CSF) was founded in 1887 by Casimiro Giacomelli, a priest of the Comboni Missionaries who had previously been posted in Sudan. CSF was a private initiative to serve the local population of Helwan (some 25km south of central Cairo) – Egyptian and foreign, Christian and Muslim. At the time of its founding, Egypt had a fledgling public education system and several churches established schools with official endorsement. Known today as the Holy Family School, it remains Helwan's oldest and most distinguished school. It has evolved from being an entirely European initiative to being an Egyptian school in all respects. Its administrators, teachers, and pupils hail largely from the local neighborhood, although a few dozen students travel from across the Nile or adjacent neighborhoods to the north. CSF-Helwan carries on as a private institution administered by the Comboni Missionaries.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Materials were placed in new acid-free folders and boxes and returned to the Collège de la Sainte Famille, Akkasah has retained digital surrogates only. Original caption information, when available, was transcribed into ArchivesSpace. The language of the original captions was retained in the digitisation of both the recto and verso of each photograph.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Collection processed in the order in which it was received.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: NYU Abu Dhabi holds all copyright and related rights pertaining to this collection. Please contact Akkasah at akkasah@nyu.edu for information regarding information and use.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Collection acquired directly from College de la Sainte Famille.
